awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding the Changing Global Distribution of Radiocarbon: Sampling and Analysis from GO-SHIP and Ships of Opportunity Cruises
awd_abstract_narration:
Radiocarbon has long been recognized as an important tracer for studies of ocean processes. The major objective of this project is to continue a systematic global resampling of the oceanic radiocarbon distribution as part of the US Global Ocean Carbon and Repeat Hydrography program, a part of the international Global Ocean Ship-Based Hydrographic Investigations Program (GO-SHIP) network of sustained observations. Continued sampling of select repeat hydrography lines as well as the collection of samples from other important regions will provide the global carbon cycle community with a robust database to test ocean general circulation models. This is particularly important based on our reliance on such models to predict the consequences of increased global carbon dioxide. 

Data generated from this study can be used to study mixing, ventilation rates, production rates, residence times in the deep ocean, deep ocean biogeochemistry and oxygen use rates, air-sea gas exchange, thermocline ventilation rates, as a proxy for anthropogenic carbon dioxide in the ocean, and to evaluate ocean general circulation model performance. The samples to be collected are focused on, but not limited to, the Indian and the Southern Oceans. The researchers will collect and analyze samples from planned repeat hydrography Atlantic cruises over the next 5 years. The total planned sampling will help provide an updated estimate of the three dimensional radiocarbon distribution for the Indian Ocean in addition to monitoring changes in the bomb-14C transient. Their repeat sampling schedule is, by design, a bit slower than for the general Repeat Hydrography program. This reduction is a compromise based on budgetary considerations, sample analysis capacity and cruise plans. They will also sample in the Southern Ocean as part of the Southern Ocean Carbon and Climate Observations and Modeling (SOCCOM) effort. These samples will document the radiocarbon distribution in this poorly understood region of the ocean and provide important information about carbon flux and transport through this area.

por.por_cntn:
The end of this grant also marks the formal end of a very successful 30 year collaboration between the principle investigators, Robert Key and Ann McNichol, and the research staff at the National Ocean Sciences Accelerator Mass Spectrometry (NOSAMS) facility at Woods Hole, MA. The resulting data set would not have been conceivable when we started and not possible without the generous and continued support of the National Science Foundation.

The primary goals of this grant and its predecessors were to:

Make sufficient open ocean radiocarbon measurements to describe the global three-dimensional distribution. For our work all measurements were made on dissolved inorganic carbon. Because of technique improvements developed by McNichol early in this project, the 13 C values were also research quality and reported along with the radiocarbon values

Produce the radiocarbon values at the lowest possible cost without sacrificing highest possible accuracy or potential scientific value.

Precisely characterize the uncertainty of the individual measurements.

Quality control the resulting values.

Report the results with no proprietary period to the appropriate data centers (CCHDO & NCEI/OCADS replaced CDIAC).

And finally, for this particular grant, to execute a succession plan so that this research can continue as the oceanic radiocarbon distribution continues to evolve.

These goals were all met.

Collection, Analysis and Data Reporting

In the following table, samples from each listed cruise were collected, analyzed, or both under funding from this grant. Because of the lag time between collection and reporting it is not uncommon for samples collected under one grant to be analyzed under a subsequent grant. The NSF/NOSAMS agreement allows for ~1000

14C/ 13 C analyses per year. That number includes duplicates, etc. and therefore will never match the number of results reported to the data repositories. There is one caveat in the listing below.

 

The number of samples analyzed is occasionally larger than the number of samples collected. The 500ml water samples produce more than enough CO2 for the 14 C/13C analyses so a significant fraction of the gas is archived. Occasionally those archived aliquots are analyzed for confirmation of original results thus explaining the apparent discrepancy.

As has been the practice throughout this entire period, McNichol was in charge of the analytical work at NOSAMS, results are reported by Kathy Elder (NOSAMS) to R. Key (PU). Key combines duplicate results as is appropriate for each set, merges the values into the existing bottle data set for that cruise, QCs the results, and reports the values, error and QC flags ( 14 C and 13C) to CCHDO and NCEI/OCADS.. Results are also routinely reported to the GLODAP team for inclusion in their products.

6/22/20 325020190403 106S 445 447 Reported
8/15/18 320620180309 S04p 442 493 Reported
10/15/18 33R020180423 107N 416 412 Reported

During  COVID, NOSAMS was able to accelerate analysis of our sample backlog due to a decrease in the input of other samples and true dedication on the part of the NOSAMS scientists and technicians. We would also like to especially recognize Al Gagnon (NOSAMS) who has for many years organized and executed cruise preparation and logistics for this project. His work always has been and continues to be exemplary. To the entire NOSAMS team we offer congratulations and a very sincere Thank You!

 
Data Quality

Data quality as measured by reproducibility of radiocarbon replicate samples was thoroughly described by Kathy Elder in 1997. That level has been maintained throughout this project. During this last grant period, we believe reproducibility has improved. We have just begun a formal analysis to investigate radiocarbon reproducibility recent years.

Succession Plan

At the beginning of 2020 Key and McNichol set out to draft a new lead team to continue our work. Rolf Sonnerup (UW) and Roberta Hansman (NOSAMS) were eventually selected and agreed. Subsequently they wrote and submitted a follow-up proposal for the next phase of GO-SHIPS repeat occupations. That proposal was funded and we are confident that the radiocarbon and 13C programs are in good hands.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 05/25/2022
Modified by: Ann P Mcnichol
